True North is about direction finding in what I call a mother lost world.

one height contained inside another.

For True North was originally a book whose cover featured an image by Joseph Cornell called Constellation.
Both covers suggest a kind of writing on uncharted space.

That is, annotated.

Each color is thus a link tracked not by software, but by human memory.

In this poem, James Clark Maxwell, father of the electronic age, discovers with delight the vector spaces and notation invented by Willard Gibbs, America's first mathematical physicist.

He seems to be at peace, stretched out on the crisp white sheets of a hospital bed, an oxygen mask strapped over his face.
He's a tall man, six foot plus, bulky and out of shape.
His spitting hair has the shoe polish flat color of a bad guy, the kind he applies once a minute while he showers.
Several shades too dark for his age.
His dark hair emphasizes the waxy luster of his skin.
If he could open his eyes, he'd see two nurses at their station on the other side of a large window.
He'd see machines mounted on walls around his bed, and more machines positioned beside him on parts.
He's alone in the room, which is hairless and smells of disinfectant.
This machine that supplies his oxygen hises, a machine that monitors his heart beats.
Another machine has a pain that's worrisome and glad.
Beyond that window, in a lounge at the end of a long harbor, his wife has brought him to reporters.

Years since anyone looked at me with such subtle signaling of passion and promise as if pleading with me to pry open the locked chambers of a secret cell.
Years.
At first, I was surprised.
Look at me.
I'm an older man.
Admittedly, women have always been drawn to what my wife describes as the animal adult of my physical body.
I am a big man.
There are women whose size doesn't even matter.
Still, I was surprised.
At first, I told myself that she was simply an attentive student.
Her eyes sort out my eyes.
She leaned forward as if about to ask a question, the silky, solid-colored blouse as she prefers buttoned high, and yet the spaces between those buttons.
When she leaned into the verge of a question, the bright flashes of creamy sand detonated deep in the primal recesses of morning, unsettling in the heavy earth of convention and decorum.
I wanted to touch her.
I wanted to cross the room, fall on my knees, and lay my head on her thigh.
I was careful, though, to keep my desires hidden.
My every expression and gesture was a model of professionalism.
I knew what she was thinking.
I could see the dance of desire deep in the dark of her eyes.
But I couldn't act.
I couldn't speak as long as I entertained even the smallest measure of doubt.
The risk was too high.
I had to be sure.
I thought, this is the moment.
Now is the time.
As she settled into her chair, I looked at her meaningfully and closed my office door slowly, signaling my intentions.
Her lips came together in what I'm almost sure was a smile.
I pulled my chair out from under my desk and placed it directly in front of her.
When I took my seat, we were needed in.
Suddenly, her eyes were firing as if the heat of passion were burning through its inner restraints.
Still, no words came.
We were mute.
I looked hungrily over her body while in my eyes to speak formally.
She seemed to want to say something.
Her face was red with desire.
Her hand shot out quickly toward the desk, and I could see she was reaching for the bar from our riverside chimney.
And it occurred to me that there was perhaps some passage from the place she thought spoke to our situation.
The book seemed literally to fly from the desk.
She rested with both hands and pulled the back of her body with great intensity.
